snippet.textDisplay: I don't know if you can hold the ff7 remake up as the best example of a nostalgic game beating every other "TRIPLE A" games. It's combat is more in line with modern it's unrecognizable from the original, it had pre orders and ce bonuses out the wazoo, oh, and the story is so stretched out that we are only getting the first third of a story. If you don't like companies walling content behind dlc, how are you going to champion Final Fantasy 7 part 1?

snippet.textDisplay:
Game development (AAA variant) is costly, and a new IP is a risky business. Just imagine throwing the same budget at FF7 remake or a new FF16. Reusing old IP cuts story/character writing, and guarantee profit from fanbase.


On a different note, I am glad to see indie games are on the rise. It has its own set of problems, but it is where fresh and innovative gaming ideas flourish.
snippet.textOriginal:
Game development (AAA variant) is costly, and a new IP is a risky business.  Just imagine throwing the same budget at FF7 remake or a new FF16.  Reusing old IP cuts story/character writing, and guarantee profit from fanbase.


On a different note, I am glad to see indie games are on the rise.  It has its own set of problems, but it is where fresh and innovative gaming ideas flourish.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think game copying has always been an issue in the game industry. In the 80s it was arcade games space Invaders had tons of clones and in then 90s it was fighting games because of mortal Kombat.
It think it's a pop culture problem, people see what works and want to take the easy way with what they've seen work already. I guess they think it's a safer path than being able to stand out as original.

snippet.textDisplay:
Another interesting thing to note about a lot of these games that seem to be doing so well is that they seem to mostly come from Japan (barring a few exceptions like Doom Eternal and Cyberpunk that have high hopes and excitement built around them), not only that but we don't tend to see anywhere near as much in the way of the much maligned and despised tactics used by Western developers in games that come from Japan either.


Now, I don't know enough about what the corporate and working culture and inner workings of devs and publishers from both regions are like to be able to speculate as to why this difference seems to exist but it's fair to say that if we want the industry to improve we probably need to take some lessons from them not just in terms of what kind of games are popular but also in terms of how to conduct business and the mindset of how devs are run and directed because they clearly seem to have their shit in order.
snippet.textOriginal:

Now, I don't know enough about what the corporate and working culture and inner workings of devs and publishers from both regions are like to be able to speculate as to why this difference seems to exist but it's fair to say that if we want the industry to improve we probably need to take some lessons from them not just in terms of what kind of games are popular but also in terms of how to conduct business and the mindset of how devs are run and directed because they clearly seem to have their shit in order.

snippet.textDisplay:
There is many other reasons for these remakes being successful
The original RE trilogy was the high point of the franchise along with it's genre, no matter how much people like RE4, that was the title that morphed the franchise into an action game and had little to do thematically with it's predecessors.
FF7 not only was the first FF of many, but FF8 and 9 had graphics that were much better and after the remakes of FF 1, 2 and 3, 7 ended up being the uglier game of the franchise, that's why people have been clamoring for a remake since the PS2.

snippet.textDisplay:
I wish I could agree, but I don't like the FFVII remake demo specifically because it is doing what you accuse Resident Evil 6 of doing: replacing the series-defining gameplay with generic, forgettable action. I don't play Final Fantasy to mash square like I'm playing Dynasty Warriors with one of the more boring characters. (Screw Zhao Yun.) For twenty years and change I've wanted a remake of FFVII which could take the story, setting characters, and gameplay that I enjoyed but bring the presentation up to a newer, more captivating standard than the original 'popeye' models and midi sound which, let's be honest, looked and sounded dated with a year of its release. And now we've got that presentation, but we've lost the gameplay. Even on 'classic' mode, that demo bears next to no resemblance to the original title, instead playing like a mash-up of FFXV, Kingdom Hearts, and Lighting Returns: Final Fantasy XIII. All of which have every right to exist, but are action games whichever way you slice them.
At this point my hope is there is eventually a PC release with enough mods to turn 'classic' mode into a true representation of the original game and not just the 'sometimes Cloud will attack on his own' pointless guff that is in that demo.
I wanted to like the demo—I reinstalled it several times and have gone through it six times now, three times on classic and three on normal—but I just can't. It's simply not what I want. In fact it is everything I never wanted; everything I have been dreading since Lightning Returns and Square's 'promise' that every game going forward would be an attack-mashing action title.

(For the record, as much as I enjoyed the RE2 remake and am keenly looking forward to the RE3 remake, I still also prefer their originals, too. I replayed the original RE2 after the remake and I do sincerely enjoy it more. Given that I've always liked RE3 more than RE2 it stands to reason that I will probably like the original RE3 over its remake as well. I'd like to be wrong on that estimation. I'd like nothing more than for the RE3 remake to blow even me away to the point I favour it over the original. But so far, we're not on track for that.)
snippet.textOriginal:
I wish I could agree, but I don't like the FFVII remake demo specifically because it is doing what you accuse Resident Evil 6 of doing: replacing the series-defining gameplay with generic, forgettable action. I don't play Final Fantasy to mash square like I'm playing Dynasty Warriors with one of the more boring characters. (Screw Zhao Yun.) For twenty years and change I've wanted a remake of FFVII which could take the story, setting characters, _and gameplay_ that I enjoyed but bring the presentation up to a newer, more captivating standard than the original 'popeye' models and midi sound which, let's be honest, looked and sounded dated with a year of its release. And now we've got that presentation, but we've lost the gameplay. Even on 'classic' mode, that demo bears next to no resemblance to the original title, instead playing like a mash-up of FFXV, Kingdom Hearts, and Lighting Returns: Final Fantasy XIII. All of which have every right to exist, but are action games whichever way you slice them. 
At this point my hope is there is eventually a PC release with enough mods to turn 'classic' mode into a true representation of the original game and not just the 'sometimes Cloud will attack on his own' pointless guff that is in that demo.
I wanted to like the demo—I reinstalled it several times and have gone through it six times now, three times on classic and three on normal—but I just can't. It's simply not what I want. In fact it is everything I _never_ wanted; everything I have been dreading since Lightning Returns and Square's 'promise' that every game going forward would be an attack-mashing action title.

(For the record, as much as I enjoyed the RE2 remake and am keenly looking forward to the RE3 remake, I still also prefer their originals, too. I replayed the original RE2 after the remake and I do sincerely enjoy it more. Given that I've always liked RE3 more than RE2 it stands to reason that I will probably like the original RE3 over its remake as well. I'd like to be wrong on that estimation. I'd like nothing more than for the RE3 remake to blow even me away to the point I favour it over the original. But so far, we're not on track for that.)

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm Italian, I live in Italy, I don't have a flu (neither the normal annual one neither the Chinese corona virus one). And here living has become basically the same as the thing they describe in zombie games for the "outbreak" phase before the events of the game itself happen. Thanks god for mass media, politicians and widely spread ignorance: now I can finally live a videogame scenario in real life! Wow!
(Please inject 20 ml of sarcasm in your brain if you cannot read the previous 2 sentences correctly)


On topic:
I think it's mainly telling us all we need to know about the status of modern game development and publishing when you combine the fact that "new" titles are published in an half baked and/or identity-less status, while remakes of waaaaay older games feel and play so smooth and nice.
I mean: in modern games' development, triple A ones in particular, they
- very often don't have a clear idea of what they want to do to begin with,
- they just as often are unable to organize a logic and straightforward working process during development
- and after they reach a playable "anything" they quite rarely manage to correctly evaluate what they produced in order to identify and correct any kind of flaw, especially in respect of experience balance, of gameplay loop difficulty vs satisfaction of the given rewards, and of length vs significance of the story narrated (if there is one in the 1st place, that is).
- As a plus one: they more and more avoid, partially or altogether, the bug fixing phase of development, which, thanks to gaming platforms being universally always online, is basically done by the paying players themselves.


When they remake an older game they already have a finished product they start from, so during development they know what they aim at (1st point of previous list), they have a reference which makes easier to have an idea of what they want to expand or shrink or bring up to date from the original material (2nd and 3rd point) and, when the original game is a masterpiece of the past, they also have a high standard of quality of the product they're publishing to satisfy (4th point).


 Thanks for your videos

snippet.textDisplay:
The reason I'm looking forward to FFVII:R is because I know that, as a game, it's finished.

Seriously. I has a beginning, a middle, and an end, and there are characters to play as, enemies to fight, little minigames to play and a map to explore. It's freakin' weird to say that out loud but I know it's a GAME and not a to-do list and so I'm probably going to get something approaching my money's worth out of it, even if I'm already 1000+ hours into the original at this point.
snippet.textOriginal:
The reason I'm looking forward to FFVII:R is because I know that, as a game, it's finished.

Seriously. I has a beginning, a middle, and an end, and there are characters to play as, enemies to fight, little minigames to play and a map to explore. It's freakin' weird to say that out loud but I know it's a GAME and not a to-do list and so I'm probably going to get something approaching my money's worth out of it, even if I'm already 1000+ hours into the original at this point.

snippet.textDisplay: If you're tired of how samey and non-envelope-pushing the games industry has become, you should look into getting into VR, Jim. The current situation in VR gaming is a return to the wild west days of early gaming, where best practices haven't been established and everyone is trying out all kinds of wild ideas, since currently no one yet has a clue about what works and what doesn't work. It's gone from "let's have people sit in a chair and control the game with a gamepad" to "you know, people might want to be able to stand up and interact with the game naturally using their hands" to "being able to track the player's fingers could allow for more natural interaction" in a few short years. Shit's pretty crazy.
snippet.textOriginal: If you're tired of how samey and non-envelope-pushing the games industry has become, you should look into getting into VR, Jim. The current situation in VR gaming is a return to the wild west days of early gaming, where best practices haven't been established and everyone is trying out all kinds of wild ideas, since currently no one yet has a clue about what works and what doesn't work. It's gone from "let's have people sit in a chair and control the game with a gamepad" to "you know, people might want to be able to stand up and interact with the game naturally using their hands" to "being able to track the player's fingers could allow for more natural interaction" in a few short years. Shit's pretty crazy.

snippet.textDisplay:
Jim I'm surprised you completely ignored the fact that these are Japanese developers only who care about the quality of their product vs. maximizing profit. I think this is a part of their culture caring more about honor than opportunity. There was another remake this year, Warcraft 3: Reforged.
The irony of this is that products made by people who put quality first typically make more money than products made by those who put profits first.
snippet.textOriginal:
Jim I'm surprised you completely ignored the fact that these are *Japanese developers only* who care about the quality of their product vs. maximizing profit. I think this is a part of their culture caring more about honor than opportunity. There was another remake this year, Warcraft 3: Reforged. 
The irony of this is that products made by people who put quality first typically make more money than products made by those who put profits first.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think a special factor in the popularity of remakes in gaming is how inaccessible old games are relative to other media.

Oh, sure, you can get out the emulator, or buy old hardware and secondhand games...
But I can't, say, take my 20 year old game and put it in a modern computer and just expect it to work without question. It MAY work. Or it may not. It may work after a lot of faffing about, or it may never work...

Contrast this to a DVD from 20 years ago, and I can put that in pretty much any DVD player and it'll just work.
For that matter, a company that wants to re-release a new version of a film can just basically reprint what already exists.
Barring format shifts from say VHS to DVD to Bluray, there's almost no effort involved.
And even the format shifts are fairly minimal effort given how they create these from the masters..

I can trivially buy a copy of an 80 year old film on a modern format and while the conversion cost for putting it on that modern format wasn't zero, it was fairly trivial.

Compare this to trying to get an old game in a workable state on modern systems and you can see why so many companies, especially with more popular games go 'fuck it. Let's just remake it entirely.'

I can buy brand new copies of 3000 year old books for the same reason.

Gaming has a very peculiar problem where you can't just replicate the game;
The game and the hardware it ran on are intimately connected.
Emulation basically exists because to get an old game to run you have to imitate the hardware it ran on as well.
So really, in preservation terms, preserving a film, book, song or whatever is generally just preserving the data that makes it up...

Preserving a game means also preserving the hardware in some capacity...

So much more difficult to keep up with, and so much more error prone.

Biggest problem with preserving films independently is actually DRM, for instance.

For games, DRM is only the first hurdle usually...

snippet.textDisplay:
Meh, FF7 the remake can kiss my ass. A split apart bullshit thing made to milk you and already characters have lost the comedic charm with a lame toned some soundtrack but people refuse to push that part because its Square! Gotta suck its dick!


Edit: Alright you have some points on why people are giving them so much slack and excitement.

snippet.textDisplay: But Resident Evil 2 was  whole game. Not split up into parts. The FF7 Remake has the problems of the modern era. It's got DLC and I wouldn't be surprised to see micro transactions in there either. It's got content taken out. Also I don't know why people are hyped by it's real time battle system straight outta FF15. I want to love the FF7 remake, but I can't not with content like Red XIII taken out.
snippet.textOriginal: But Resident Evil 2 was  whole game. Not split up into parts. The FF7 Remake has the problems of the modern era. It's got DLC and I wouldn't be surprised to see micro transactions in there either. It's got content taken out. Also I don't know why people are hyped by it's real time battle system straight outta FF15. I want to love the FF7 remake, but I can't not with content like Red XIII taken out.

snippet.textDisplay:
No mention of CDPR delaying CP2077 for QA? Might as well beat all the remake titles if they manage to pull off what they promised and is expected. Also no mentioning of the splitting of FF7's story into multiple parts to sell FF7-R as a possible 4-Part series? Must be Corona', you're usually not that sloppy...
Also, thank you for repeatedly calling out the AAAs for their bullshit. Sometimes I think it would be best if game companies were forced to stop growing at A-Level, and forbid managers with no gaming expertise to become ceo of game developers and publishers...
